awd_titl_txt: Achieving Change in our Communities for Equity and Student Success (ACCESS) in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) Track 1 program, the Achieving Change in our Communities for Equity and Student Success (ACCESS) in STEM program will recruit high-achieving, low-income students to become STEM majors at the University of Washington at Tacoma. The program will support the retention and academic success of 36 students by providing focused mentoring, a living-learning community, course-based undergraduate research experiences, and two years of targeted scholarship support. Mentoring activities will include group and one-on-one faculty mentoring in three 12-person cohorts, skills workshops, and a focus group on equity and inclusion in STEM to help develop a sense of community, identity, and empowerment. 

Taken together, this ACCESS program will provide supports and experiences that enable more low-income, academically high achieving students to graduate with STEM degrees, bringing a pipeline of talented and skilled professionals into the workforce. In addition, using their increased cultural competencies, the ACCESS research experience will engage students in an interdisciplinary, community-use inspired study of environmental pollution that affects a local Native American tribe. The aim is to prepare ACCESS scholars to help transform the STEM workplace into a more inclusive and welcoming environment. The program team will quantitatively and qualitatively assess the effectiveness of equity- and inclusivity-focused mentoring, that is coupled with community-engaged, socially relevant, early research experiences.  The results of this research may inform other institutions seeking to support the success of low-income students in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
S-STEM Project Outcomes Report

The overall goal of the Achieving Change for our Communities for Equity and Student Success (ACCESS) in STEM program at the University of Washington Tacoma (UWT) was to provide support during their crucial first two years for low income, talented students who are interested in STEM majors. The program offered focused faculty and peer mentoring, a living learning community, course-based undergraduate research experiences, and scholarship support with a goal of increasing recruitment to STEM majors, retention in STEM majors, academic success, and graduation rates of our scholars. Our Success in STEM freshman and sophomore seminar centered peer and near-peer mentoring and provided workshops on academic and professional skills to promote a sense of community, identity, and empowerment. We also sought to understand the factors that impact student success, with particular attention to self-efficacy, sense of belonging, career goals, science identity, and awareness of equity and inclusion in STEM via surveys and focus group interviews.


From 2018 to 2024, we supported 48 ACCESS scholars from Computer Science, Mathematics, Environmental Science, and Biomedical Sciences majors, spread over four cohorts. The diversity of our scholars matched or exceeded that of our campus as a whole; 56% were female, 6% were dependents of veterans, and 73% will be first in their family to achieve a college degree. Racial/ethnic minorities that are underrepresented in STEM constituted 40% of the group; 22% identified as African or African-American, 2% Hawaiian/Pacific Islander, and 7% Hispanic; an additional 30% identified as Asian or Asian-American, 26% as Caucasian non-Hispanic, and 11% more than one race/ethnicity. 


Program participants had higher retention and cumulative GPAs, shorter time to degree, and a greater proportion had entered a STEM major by their second year compared to eligible, non-program students. In particular, second year retention was 80% for the program and only 66% for eligible non-program students. Students in the program reported higher self-efficacy in science and math, science and math identity, and sense of belonging, and lower collegiate stress than the comparison group, and interview responses suggested that relationships built through mentoring were crucial, and may have provided some protection from the impacts of remote learning during the pandemic. These outcomes were reported at the national American Association for the Advancement of Science S-STEM conference in 2022 and the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) conferences in 2023 and 2024, and have resulted in three peer-reviewed papers and a manuscript under review. 


Intellectual Merit


Our research experience course has demonstrated a novel approach to engaging first year students in the process of science. Our interdisciplinary team-based approach has allowed us to test the impact of combining the two high impact practices of course-based undergraduate research and community-engaged learning for first year students across multiple STEM majors. More generally, our research has demonstrated how mentoring and support can promote choice and autonomy to explore varied academic options which is important for the success of first- and second year STEM-interested students.


 

Broader Impacts


By supporting low income, talented, diverse students and recruiting them to consider majoring in a STEM discipline, we have strengthened pathways to STEM careers. Our Success in STEM seminar has a broad impact by providing support to first and second year STEM-interested students and both this course and our first year course-based undergraduate research class have become institutionalized to provide a resource to all STEM-interested students, not just those in the ACCESS in STEM program. The program has engaged 38 faculty in mentoring students, with the accompanying training focused on practices that promote equity and inclusion. As our ACCESS scholars develop a strong sense of identity and empowerment, and as our faculty develop increased cultural humility and enhanced skills for effective mentoring of low income, first generation in college, and underrepresented women and racial/ethnic minority students, these impacts benefit all students that our faculty interact with throughout their careers, as well as the colleagues they interact with and mentor.


Perhaps partly due to these broader impacts across our campus, during the six years this program has been in effect at UWT, the number of students graduating with STEM majors increased from 345 (84 women) to 416 (137 women), and the proportion of students graduating with a STEM major increased from 25% (11% for women) to 31% (20% for women). By increasing the socioeconomic and gender balance of students in STEM majors at UWT, the program has already begun to impact society by opening doors of opportunity for talented, low income students, helping them to gain access to modern, high value career pathways in STEM industries.


 


Last Modified: 07/29/2024
Modified by: Erica Cline
